      "text": "# Problem Statement

Let $k\geq 3$ and $f(k)$ be the supremum of $\sum_{n\in A}\frac{1}{n}$ as $A$ ranges over all sets of positive integers which do not contain a $k$-term arithmetic progression. 

(i) Estimate $f(k)$.

(ii) Is

\[\lim_{k\to \infty}\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}=\infty\]where $W(k)$ 

is the van der Waerden number?

---

# Background Information to the Problem

Berlekamp \cite{Be68} proved $f(k) \geq \frac{\log 2}{2}k$. Gerver \cite{Ge77} proved\[f(k) \geq (1-o(1))k\log k.\]It is trivial that\[\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}\geq \frac{1}{2},\]but improving the right-hand side to any constant $>1/2$ is open.

Gerver also proved (see the comments for an alternative argument of Tao) that [3] is equivalent to $f(k)$ being finite for all $k$.

The current record for $f(3)$ is $f(3)\geq 3.00849$, due to Wr\'{o}blewski \cite{Wr84}. Walker \cite{Wa25} proved $f(4)\geq 4.43975$.

Walker \cite{Wa25} has shown that it suffices to consider Kempner sets (that is, sets of integers defined as all those whose base $b$ digits are contained in some $S\subset \{0,\ldots,b-1\}$ for fixed $b$ and $S$), in the sense that for any $k\geq 3$ and $\epsilon>0$ there is a Kempner set $A$ lacking $k$-term arithmetic progressions such that\[\sum_{n\in A}\frac{1}{n}\geq f(k)-\epsilon.\]

## References

[Be68] Berlekamp, E. R., A construction for partitions which avoid long arithmetic progressions. Canad. Math. Bull. (1968), 409-414.

[Ge77] Gerver, Joseph L., The sum of the reciprocals of a set of integers with no arithmetic progression of {$k$} terms. Proc. Amer. Math. Soc. (1977), 211--214.

[Wa25] A. Walker, Integer sets of large harmonic sum which avoid long arithmetic progressions. arXiv:2203.06045 (2025).

[Wr84] No reference found."
    },
    {
      "role": "user",
      "text": "# Solution Attempt 1 by the PROBLEM_SOLVER

Status: Partial

Response to last solution evaluation: no evaluation of previous solution attempt provided

## Solution

### 0. Definitions and basic monotonicity

Fix an integer \(k\ge 3\). Let \(A\subset \mathbb{Z}_{>0}\) be **\(k\)-AP-free** if it contains no \(k\)-term arithmetic progression
\[
a,\, a+d,\, a+2d,\,\dots,\, a+(k-1)d \qquad (d\neq 0).
\]
Define
\[
f(k)\ :=\ \sup\Bigl\{\sum_{n\in A}\frac1n \,:\, A\subset\mathbb{Z}_{>0}\text{ is \(k\)-AP-free}\Bigr\}\in [0,\infty].
\]

Two immediate properties:

1. **Monotonicity in \(k\):** If \(k\le \ell\), then every \(k\)-AP-free set is \(\ell\)-AP-free, hence
   \[
   f(k)\le f(\ell).
   \]

2. **Connection to the Erdős–Turán (Erdős) conjecture on arithmetic progressions:**  
   The conjecture asserts that if \(\sum_{n\in A} \frac1n=\infty\), then \(A\) contains arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions. This is equivalent to the statement that \(f(k)<\infty\) for every \(k\ge 3\). (This equivalence is explicitly noted in Walker’s discussion of \(f(k)\).) ([ar5iv.org](https://ar5iv.org/pdf/2203.06045))

So part (i) necessarily splits into: what we can prove unconditionally (lower bounds), what is known conditionally if \(f(k)\) is finite, and what is known for small \(k\).

---

### 1. A “trivial” but important lower bound in terms of \(W(k)\)

Let \(W(k)=W(2,k)\) denote the **two-color van der Waerden number**: the least integer \(N\) such that every 2-coloring of \(\{1,2,\dots,N\}\) contains a monochromatic \(k\)-term arithmetic progression.

There exists a 2-coloring of \(\{1,\dots,W(k)-1\}\) with **no** monochromatic \(k\)-AP. Let the two color classes be \(R\) and \(B\). Then both \(R\) and \(B\) are \(k\)-AP-free.

Now
\[
\sum_{n\in R}\frac1n\;+\;\sum_{n\in B}\frac1n \;=\; \sum_{n=1}^{W(k)-1}\frac1n \;=\; H_{W(k)-1},
\]
so one of the two sums is at least \(H_{W(k)-1}/2\). Therefore
\[
f(k)\ \ge\ \frac12\,H_{W(k)-1}.
\]
Using \(H_m=\log m+\gamma+o(1)\), we get the asymptotic form
\[
f(k)\ \ge\ \frac12\log W(k)\;+\;O(1).
\]
This is the “trivial” inequality mentioned in the problem background: \(\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}\ge \frac12\) up to lower-order terms. ([erdosproblems.com](https://www.erdosproblems.com/forum/thread/169?utm_source=openai))

**Remark.** Improving the constant \(\tfrac12\) in a uniform way (e.g. showing \(\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}\ge \frac12+\delta\) for any fixed \(\delta>0\)) is currently open, as noted in the same source. ([erdosproblems.com](https://www.erdosproblems.com/forum/thread/169?utm_source=openai))

---

### 2. Best known general lower bounds for \(f(k)\)

#### 2.1 Berlekamp’s linear bound
Berlekamp proved a construction giving
\[
f(k)\ \ge\ \frac{\log 2}{2}\,k.
\]
This is recorded in the standard references on this problem. ([erdosproblems.com](https://www.erdosproblems.com/forum/thread/169?utm_source=openai))

#### 2.2 Gerver’s \((1-o(1))k\log k\) bound (as \(k\to\infty\))
Gerver proved a substantially stronger asymptotic lower bound:
for every \(\varepsilon>0\), for all sufficiently large \(k\) there exists a \(k\)-AP-free set \(S_k\) with
\[
\sum_{n\in S_k}\frac1n\ >\ (1-\varepsilon)\,k\log k.
\]
Equivalently,
\[
f(k)\ \ge\ (1-o(1))\,k\log k\qquad (k\to\infty).
\]
This is stated as the main theorem in Gerver’s paper and is quoted in the problem background. ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/9125569/the-sum-of-the-reciprocals-of-a-set-of-integers-with?utm_source=openai))

So, **unconditionally**, the best general lower bound currently on record is
\[
f(k)\ \ge\ (1-o(1))k\log k.
\]

---

### 3. What is known about finiteness / upper bounds?

This is where the main difficulty lies: for \(k\ge 4\) it is unknown whether \(f(k)\) is finite at all.

#### 3.1 The case \(k=3\): \(f(3)<\infty\) is known
Bloom and Sisask proved that if \(A\subset\{1,\dots,N\}\) is 3-AP-free then \(|A|\ll N/(\log N)^{1+c}\) for some absolute \(c>0\). ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.03528?utm_source=openai))  
This “breaks the logarithmic barrier” in Roth-type bounds and implies:

> Any 3-AP-free set \(A\subset\mathbb{Z}_{>0}\) has \(\sum_{n\in A} \frac1n<\infty\).

Sketch of the deduction (standard partial summation argument): let \(A(x)=|A\cap[1,x]|\). Then
\[
\sum_{\substack{n\in A\\ n\le N}}\frac1n
= \frac{A(N)}{N}+\int_1^N \frac{A(x)}{x^2}\,dx.
\]
If \(A(x)\ll x/(\log x)^{1+c}\), then \(\int_2^\infty \frac{dx}{x(\log x)^{1+c}}<\infty\), giving convergence. Hence \(f(3)<\infty\). Walker explicitly notes that Bloom–Sisask’s work establishes finiteness of \(f(3)\), while \(f(k)\) for \(k>3\) remains unknown. ([ar5iv.org](https://ar5iv.org/pdf/2203.06045))

#### 3.2 The cases \(k\ge 4\): finiteness of \(f(k)\) is open
For longer progressions, quantitative forms of Szemerédi’s theorem give bounds of the form
\[
r_k(N):=\max\{|A|:A\subset[1,N]\text{ is \(k\)-AP-free}\}\le \frac{N}{(\log\log N)^{c_k}}
\]
for some very small \(c_k>0\) (depending on \(k\)), but such bounds are far too weak to imply convergence of \(\sum_{n\in A}\frac1n\). ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Szemer%C3%A9di%27s_theorem?utm_source=openai))

Thus, for \(k\ge 4\), it is currently consistent with known results that:

- \(f(k)\) is finite but extremely large, or
- \(f(k)=\infty\) (which would refute the Erdős–Turán conjecture).

No unconditional nontrivial upper bound of the form \(f(k)\le C(k)\) is known for \(k\ge 4\), because producing such a bound is essentially as hard as proving the conjecture for that \(k\). ([erdosproblems.com](https://www.erdosproblems.com/forum/thread/169?utm_source=openai))

---

### 4. Numerical / small-\(k\) records

The problem statement also mentions best known explicit lower bounds for small \(k\), which are part of the “estimate” landscape:

- \(f(3)\ge 3.00849\) due to Wróblewski (1984). ([math.stackexchange.com](https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/114504/arithmetic-progressions?utm_source=openai))
- \(f(4)\ge 4.43975\) due to Alexander Walker (paper last revised September 2025 on arXiv). ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2203.06045))

Walker’s work also shows a reduction: for every \(k\) and \(\varepsilon>0\), there is a **Kempner (digit-restricted) set** \(A\) that is \(k\)-AP-free with harmonic sum within \(\varepsilon\) of \(f(k)\). ([ar5iv.org](https://ar5iv.org/pdf/2203.06045))  
So, in principle, estimating \(f(k)\) can be reduced to optimizing over a structured family of digit-restriction constructions, though this does not yet yield asymptotics.

---

### 5. Answer to (i): “Estimate \(f(k)\)”

Given the above, the most honest “estimate” one can currently provide is a range of **provable lower bounds** plus the status of upper bounds/finite vs infinite.

#### 5.1 Unconditional lower bounds
For large \(k\),
\[
f(k)\ \ge\ (1-o(1))\,k\log k \qquad \text{(Gerver).}
\]
Also for every \(k\),
\[
f(k)\ \ge\ \frac12H_{W(k)-1}\ =\ \frac12\log W(k)+O(1).
\]
And a weaker but explicit-in-\(k\) bound is
\[
f(k)\ \ge\ \frac{\log 2}{2}\,k.
\]
All of these are standard recorded bounds. ([paperzz.com](https://paperzz.com/doc/9125569/the-sum-of-the-reciprocals-of-a-set-of-integers-with?utm_source=openai))

#### 5.2 Upper bounds / finiteness
- \(f(3)<\infty\) is known (Bloom–Sisask), hence the Erdős conjecture holds for 3-term progressions. ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.03528?utm_source=openai))
- For \(k\ge 4\), it is open whether \(f(k)<\infty\). ([ar5iv.org](https://ar5iv.org/pdf/2203.06045))

So, for \(k\ge 4\), the best available “estimate” is:  
\[
(1-o(1))k\log k \ \le\ f(k)\ \le\ \infty,
\]
with the finiteness question being a major open problem.

---

### 6. Answer to (ii): does \(\displaystyle\lim_{k\to\infty}\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}=\infty\)?

#### 6.1 What we can prove
We can prove only the universal lower bound
\[
\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}\ \ge\ \frac12+o(1),
\]
coming from the harmonic-sum averaging argument in §1. ([erdosproblems.com](https://www.erdosproblems.com/forum/thread/169?utm_source=openai))

#### 6.2 Why this is open (and stronger than the known “\(\tfrac12\)” barrier)
The background states that even improving \(\tfrac12\) to any fixed constant \(>\tfrac12\) is open. ([erdosproblems.com](https://www.erdosproblems.com/forum/thread/169?utm_source=openai))  
If one cannot even prove \(\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}\ge 0.5001\) for all large \(k\), then proving that the ratio tends to \(+\infty\) is presently out of reach with current methods.

#### 6.3 Heuristic expectation (conditional discussion)
There is experimental/heuristic evidence in the van der Waerden literature that \(W(r,k)\) might behave like roughly \(r^k\) in some regimes (in particular, for fixed \(r\) and growing \(k\)). ([combinatorialpress.com](https://combinatorialpress.com/jcmcc-articles/volume-128/new-lower-bounds-for-van-der-waerden-numbers-using-distributed-computing/?utm_source=openai))  
If (purely heuristically) one had \(\log W(k)\asymp k\), then combining Gerver’s lower bound \(f(k)\gtrsim k\log k\) would suggest
\[
\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}\ \gtrsim\ \log k \ \to\ \infty.
\]
But such an upper bound \(\log W(k)=O(k)\) is far beyond what is known rigorously, so this does **not** resolve (ii).

#### 6.4 Logical alternative if \(f(k)=\infty\) for some \(k\)
If the Erdős–Turán conjecture fails for some \(k_0\), then \(f(k_0)=\infty\), and because \(f(k)\) is nondecreasing in \(k\), one would have \(f(k)=\infty\) for all \(k\ge k_0\). In that scenario, the ratio \(\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}\) is trivially \(+\infty\) for large \(k\), so the answer to (ii) would be “yes”, but at the cost of a major conjecture being false. This logical point is noted in discussions of the problem. ([erdosproblems.com](https://www.erdosproblems.com/forum/thread/169?utm_source=openai))

**Conclusion for (ii):** Open.

---

## Gaps

### Gap 1: True asymptotic order of \(f(k)\) (even finiteness) for \(k\ge 4\)
- **Location:** Part (i), “upper bounds / finiteness”.
- **Description:** For \(k\ge 4\), it is unknown whether \(f(k)\) is finite, so no genuine two-sided estimate is currently possible.
- **Reason for difficulty:** Proving \(f(k)<\infty\) is essentially the Erdős–Turán conjecture for \(k\)-term progressions, which is open beyond \(k=3\). Existing quantitative Szemerédi bounds are too weak to imply convergence of \(\sum_{n\in A}1/n\). ([erdosproblems.com](https://www.erdosproblems.com/forum/thread/169?utm_source=openai))

### Gap 2: The limit in (ii)
- **Location:** Part (ii).
- **Description:** Whether \(\lim_{k\to\infty} f(k)/\log W(k)=\infty\) is not settled by current techniques; even proving \(\liminf > 1/2\) is open.
- **Reason for difficulty:** One needs substantially stronger lower bounds on \(f(k)\) *in terms of* \(W(k)\), or significantly better understanding/bounds on \(W(k)\) itself, neither of which are currently available. ([erdosproblems.com](https://www.erdosproblems.com/forum/thread/169?utm_source=openai))

---

- No substantive mathematical gaps in the **proved** statements (the averaging argument for the \(\tfrac12\) bound, monotonicity, and the implication “Bloom–Sisask bound \(\Rightarrow f(3)<\infty\)” are standard).

- Part (ii): Gave the trivial lower bound \(\ge 1/2\) with proof, explained why the limit question is open, and discussed conditional/heuristic implications."

## Minor issues
- **§1 (“trivial bound” via \(W(k)\)) — slight loss of strength / clarity.**  
  You state \(f(k)\ge \tfrac12\log W(k)+O(1)\) and hence \(\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}\ge \tfrac12+o(1)\). One can actually record the **clean exact inequality**
  \[
  f(k)\ \ge\ \frac12\,H_{W(k)-1}\ \ge\ \frac12\log W(k),
  \]
  using \(H_{n}\ge \log(n+1)\). This would align exactly with the background statement “\(\ge 1/2\) is trivial”.  
  *Suggestion:* state both the exact inequality and the asymptotic.

- **§3.2 (“quantitative Szemerédi” bound) — imprecise and sourced weakly.**  
  The asserted form \(r_k(N)\le N/(\log\log N)^{c_k}\) is not central to your argument, but as stated it is (i) not justified, and (ii) potentially inaccurate depending on the best-known bound and the precise \(k\).  
  *Suggestion:* either (a) omit the explicit shape and just say “all known quantitative Szemerédi bounds are far too weak to force convergence of \(\sum_{n\in A}1/n\)”, or (b) cite a primary source and give the correct quantitative form for the relevant \(k\).

- **§3.1 (Bloom–Sisask \(\Rightarrow f(3)<\infty\)) — proof sketch could be made fully explicit.**  
  The partial summation formula is correct, but you should specify that \(A(x)\le Cx/(\log x)^{1+c}\) holds for all sufficiently large \(x\) with an absolute constant \(C\), and then the integral test yields a uniform bound on partial sums.  
  *Suggestion:* write the Stieltjes/partial summation step carefully (one or two lines is enough).

- **References / attribution.**  
  You repeatedly cite mirrors/secondary pages (ar5iv, paperzz, erdosproblems forum, Wikipedia, Math.SE). This is not a logical flaw, but it weakens exam-level reliability.

  You set \(W(k)=W(2,k)\), which is almost certainly what the problem intends (given the “\(\tfrac12\)” argument).  
  *Suggestion:* say explicitly “I interpret \(W(k)\) as the 2-colour van der Waerden number \(W(2,k)\)”.

## Established building blocks
- **EBB-ID-MONO-FK:** *Monotonicity of \(f(k)\) in \(k\).*  
  Your observation that “\(k\)-AP-free \(\Rightarrow \ell\)-AP-free for \(\ell\ge k\)” and hence \(f(k)\le f(\ell)\) is correct and reusable.

- **EBB-ID-VW-HALF:** *Van der Waerden averaging lower bound.*  
  The argument using a 2-colouring of \([1,W(k)-1]\) with no monochromatic \(k\)-AP to obtain  
  \[
  f(k)\ge \frac12\,H_{W(k)-1}
  \]
  is correct and is precisely the standard “trivial \(\tfrac12\)” lower bound.

- **EBB-ID-PSUM-CRIT:** *Partial summation criterion for convergence of \(\sum_{n\in A}1/n\).*  
  The formula
  \[
  \sum_{\substack{n\in A\\ n\le N}}\frac1n
  = \frac{A(N)}{N}+\int_1^N \frac{A(x)}{x^2}\,dx
  \]
  and the deduction that \(A(x)\ll x/(\log x)^{1+c}\) implies convergence are standard and correct. This is a sound block to reuse for the implication “Roth-type bounds \(\Rightarrow f(3)<\infty\)”.

## Gap assessment
You listed two gaps; both are indeed genuine and not “missing steps” in your write-up.

- **Gap 1: asymptotics / finiteness for \(k\ge 4\).**  
  **Assessment:** Fundamental.  
  This is essentially the Erdős–Turán conjecture for \(k\)-term APs (for fixed \(k\)), which is open beyond \(k=3\).

- **Gap 2: the limit \(\lim_{k\to\infty} f(k)/\log W(k)\).**  
  **Assessment:** Fundamental.  
  As you correctly note, even showing a uniform improvement over \(1/2\) is open in current literature; therefore the divergence of the ratio is far beyond what is presently proved.

## Coverage assessment
All subparts addressed: Yes.

- **Part (i):** You accurately reported the best-known general lower bounds and the finiteness status (known only for \(k=3\), open for \(k\ge 4\)).  
- **Part (ii):** You correctly identified it as open and explained why the “\(\tfrac12\)” barrier is the current unconditional baseline.

## Summary
Your write-up functions as a reasonable survey-style answer: it gives the correct definition of \(f(k)\), proves the standard van der Waerden lower bound \(f(k)\ge \tfrac12 H_{W(k)-1}\), records the major known lower bounds (Berlekamp linear and Gerver \((1-o(1))k\log k\)), and correctly explains that finiteness is known only for \(k=3\) (via Roth-type density bounds strong enough to make \(\sum 1/n\) converge). You also correctly state that for \(k\ge 4\) finiteness is open, and that the limit question in (ii) is open (indeed stronger than currently accessible). The mathematics you actually *prove* in the attempt (monotonicity, the van der Waerden averaging argument, and the partial summation implication) is correct.

The main weaknesses are presentational/rigour-attribution issues: you sometimes give an imprecise form of quantitative Szemerédi bounds and rely on weak secondary sources; and some key deductions are sketched rather than written in a fully self-contained way. None of these are fatal, but tightening them would make the exposition exam-grade. The “heuristic” comments about \(W(k)\) are fine as heuristics but should remain clearly separated from the rigorous core (which you mostly did).

Overall, as an “estimate + status” response to an open-ended/open-problem-flavoured question, the approach is sound and close to what one can responsibly say without proving new results.

1. **State the exact “trivial” inequality cleanly:** record \(f(k)\ge \tfrac12 H_{W(k)-1}\ge \tfrac12\log W(k)\) (no \(O(1)\) needed for the core inequality).
2. **Make the Bloom–Sisask \(\Rightarrow f(3)<\infty\) deduction fully explicit:** write the partial summation step with \(A(x)\) and show the integral converges (one tight paragraph).
3. **Remove or sharpen the quantitative Szemerédi claim:** either drop the explicit \(N/(\log\log N)^{c_k}\) form or replace it with a correct, sourced statement from primary literature.
4. **Use primary sources for the key facts:** cite Berlekamp (1968), Gerver (1977), Bloom–Sisask (2020), Walker (arXiv). Treat discussion forums as secondary commentary only.
5. **Clarify the definition of \(W(k)\):** explicitly fix \(W(k)=W(2,k)\) (2-colour), matching the averaging argument.

### 1. Definitions and a basic monotonicity fact

For an integer \(k\ge 3\), call a set \(A\subset \mathbb{Z}_{>0}\) **\(k\)-AP-free** if it contains no (nontrivial) \(k\)-term arithmetic progression
\[
a,\ a+d,\ a+2d,\ \dots,\ a+(k-1)d \qquad (d\neq 0).
\]
Define
\[
f(k)\ :=\ \sup\Bigl\{\ \sum_{n\in A}\frac1n\ :\ A\subset\mathbb{Z}_{>0}\text{ is \(k\)-AP-free}\ \Bigr\}\ \in [0,\infty].
\]

**Monotonicity (EBB-ID-MONO-FK).** If \(k\le \ell\), then every \(k\)-AP-free set is also \(\ell\)-AP-free (a \(\ell\)-AP contains a \(k\)-AP as a subprogression). Hence
\[
f(k)\ \le\ f(\ell).
\]

This also implies: if \(f(k_0)=\infty\) for some \(k_0\), then \(f(k)=\infty\) for all \(k\ge k_0\).

### 2. The “trivial” lower bound from van der Waerden numbers (clean exact form)

Let \(W(k)\) denote the **two-colour van der Waerden number** \(W(2,k)\): the least integer \(N\) such that every 2-colouring of \(\{1,\dots,N\}\) yields a monochromatic \(k\)-term arithmetic progression.

Let \(H_N=\sum_{n=1}^N \frac1n\) be the \(N\)-th harmonic number.

#### Lemma 2.1 (harmonic numbers dominate logs)
For every integer \(N\ge 1\),
\[
H_N\ \ge\ \log(N+1).
\]

**Proof.** Since \(x\mapsto 1/x\) is decreasing,
\[
\sum_{n=1}^N \frac1n\ \ge\ \int_{1}^{N+1}\frac{dx}{x}\ =\ \log(N+1).\qedhere
\]

#### Proposition 2.2 (van der Waerden averaging; EBB-ID-VW-HALF)
For every \(k\ge 3\),
\[
f(k)\ \ge\ \frac12\,H_{W(k)-1}\ \ge\ \frac12\log W(k),
\]
and in particular
\[
\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}\ \ge\ \frac12\qquad\text{for all }k\ge 3.
\]

**Proof.** By definition of \(W(k)\), there exists a 2-colouring of \([1,W(k)-1]\) with **no** monochromatic \(k\)-term AP. Let \(R,B\) be the two colour classes. Then both \(R\) and \(B\) are \(k\)-AP-free, so \(\sum_{n\in R}\frac1n\le f(k)\) and \(\sum_{n\in B}\frac1n\le f(k)\). But
\[
\sum_{n\in R}\frac1n+\sum_{n\in B}\frac1n\ =\ \sum_{n=1}^{W(k)-1}\frac1n\ =\ H_{W(k)-1}.
\]
Hence \(\max(\sum_{n\in R}1/n,\sum_{n\in B}1/n)\ge \frac12H_{W(k)-1}\), and thus \(f(k)\ge \frac12H_{W(k)-1}\). The inequality \(\frac12H_{W(k)-1}\ge \frac12\log W(k)\) follows from Lemma 2.1 with \(N=W(k)-1\). \(\qed\)

This is exactly the “\(\ge \tfrac12\)” baseline mentioned in the background. ([erdosproblems.com](https://www.erdosproblems.com/sources_bib/ErGr79?utm_source=openai))

### 4. Upper bounds / finiteness status

#### 4.1 A general convergence criterion (partial summation; EBB-ID-PSUM-CRIT)

For a set \(A\subset\mathbb{Z}_{>0}\), define its counting function
\[
A(x)\ :=\ |A\cap [1,x]|.
\]

##### Lemma 4.1 (partial summation for \(\sum_{n\in A}1/n\))
For any \(N\ge 1\),
\[
\sum_{\substack{n\in A\\ n\le N}}\frac1n
\;=\;
\frac{A(N)}{N}+\int_{1}^{N}\frac{A(x)}{x^{2}}\,dx,
\]
where the integral is an ordinary Riemann integral (since \(A(x)\) is piecewise constant with jumps).

**Proof.** Write \(S(N):=\sum_{n\le N,\,n\in A}1/n\). Consider \(A(x)\) as a step function with jumps of size \(1\) at each \(n\in A\). Then
\[
S(N)=\int_{1^-}^{N}\frac{1}{x}\,dA(x).
\]
Integration by parts (Stieltjes) gives
\[
\int_{1^-}^{N}\frac{1}{x}\,dA(x)
=
\Bigl[\frac{A(x)}{x}\Bigr]_{1^-}^{N}+\int_{1}^{N}A(x)\,d\Bigl(\frac{-1}{x}\Bigr)
=
\frac{A(N)}{N}+\int_{1}^{N}\frac{A(x)}{x^{2}}\,dx,
\]
since \(A(1^-)=0\). \(\qed\)

##### Corollary 4.2
If there exist constants \(C>0\), \(\delta>0\), and \(x_0\ge 2\) such that for all \(x\ge x_0\),
\[
A(x)\ \le\ \frac{C x}{(\log x)^{1+\delta}},
\]
then \(\sum_{n\in A}1/n\) converges.

**Proof.** By Lemma 4.1, for \(N\ge x_0\),
\[
\sum_{\substack{n\in A\\ n\le N}}\frac1n
\le
1+\int_{1}^{x_0}\frac{A(x)}{x^{2}}dx+\int_{x_0}^{N}\frac{C x}{(\log x)^{1+\delta}}\cdot \frac{1}{x^{2}}dx
=
O(1)+C\int_{x_0}^{N}\frac{dx}{x(\log x)^{1+\delta}}.
\]
The integral \(\int_{x_0}^{\infty} \frac{dx}{x(\log x)^{1+\delta}}\) converges for \(\delta>0\). Hence the partial sums are uniformly bounded and converge. \(\qed\)

#### 4.2 The case \(k=3\): \(f(3)<\infty\) is known
Bloom and Sisask proved a quantitative Roth bound: if \(A\subset\{1,\dots,N\}\) has no nontrivial 3-term AP, then
\[
|A|\ \ll\ \frac{N}{(\log N)^{1+c}}
\]
for some absolute \(c>0\). ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.03528?utm_source=openai))

Applying Corollary 4.2 with \(A(x)\ll x/(\log x)^{1+c}\) shows:

\[
\text{Every 3-AP-free }A\subset\mathbb{Z}_{>0}\text{ has }\sum_{n\in A}\frac1n<\infty,
\]
hence
\[
f(3)\ <\ \infty.
\]

So the Erdős–Turán conjecture (“divergent reciprocal sum \(\Rightarrow\) arbitrarily long APs”) is proved in the first nontrivial case \(k=3\). ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/abs/2007.03528?utm_source=openai))

#### 4.3 The cases \(k\ge 4\): finiteness of \(f(k)\) is open
For \(k\ge 4\), it is currently unknown whether \(f(k)\) is finite (equivalently, whether every \(k\)-AP-free set has convergent reciprocal sum). This is part of the broader Erdős–Turán conjecture program and is explicitly recorded as open in the Erdős Problems entry for this question. ([erdosproblems.com](https://www.erdosproblems.com/sources_bib/ErGr79?utm_source=openai))

Importantly: although Szemerédi’s theorem implies that \(k\)-AP-free subsets of \(\{1,\dots,N\}\) have density \(o(1)\), the known quantitative bounds for \(k\ge 4\) are nowhere near strong enough to force a decay like \(1/(\log N)^{1+\delta}\) needed for convergence of \(\sum_{n\in A}1/n\). (So one cannot currently deduce finiteness of \(f(k)\) for \(k\ge 4\) from known quantitative Szemerédi bounds.)

## (i) Estimate \(f(k)\)

### Unconditional lower bounds

#### A “trivial” but fundamental bound in terms of van der Waerden numbers
Let \(W(k)=W(2,k)\) be the 2-colour van der Waerden number: the least \(N\) such that every 2-colouring of \(\{1,\dots,N\}\) contains a monochromatic \(k\)-term AP.

Let \(H_N:=\sum_{n=1}^N \frac1n\) be the \(N\)-th harmonic number. Since \(H_N\ge \int_1^{N+1}\frac{dx}{x}=\log(N+1)\), we have \(H_{W(k)-1}\ge \log W(k)\).

Now choose a 2-colouring of \(\{1,\dots,W(k)-1\}\) with no monochromatic \(k\)-AP (this exists by minimality of \(W(k)\)), and let \(R,B\) be the two colour classes. Then both \(R\) and \(B\) are \(k\)-AP-free, and
\[
\sum_{n\in R}\frac1n+\sum_{n\in B}\frac1n \;=\; \sum_{n=1}^{W(k)-1}\frac1n \;=\; H_{W(k)-1}.
\]
So at least one of the two sums is \(\ge \tfrac12 H_{W(k)-1}\), and therefore
\[
f(k)\ \ge\ \frac12\,H_{W(k)-1}\ \ge\ \frac12\log W(k).
\]
In particular,
\[
\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}\ \ge\ \frac12\qquad\text{for all }k\ge 3.
\]

(One way to view this is via a partition/colouring construction on \(2^k\) consecutive integers yielding two \(k\)-AP-free classes and then averaging the harmonic sum.) citeturn1search0

#### Gerver’s \((1-o(1))k\log k\) lower bound
Gerver proved the substantially stronger asymptotic lower bound
\[
f(k)\ \ge\ (1-o(1))\,k\log k\qquad (k\to\infty).
\]
Equivalently: for every \(\varepsilon>0\) and all sufficiently large \(k\), there exists a \(k\)-AP-free set \(A\) with \(\sum_{n\in A}\frac1n>(1-\varepsilon)k\log k\). citeturn1search8

So, unconditionally, the best general growth lower bound currently on record is
\[
f(k)\ \gtrsim\ k\log k\qquad (k\to\infty).
\]

---

### What is known about upper bounds / finiteness?

This is where the main open difficulty lies. The overarching Erdős–Turán “sum of reciprocals” conjecture asserts that if \(\sum_{n\in A}\frac1n=\infty\) then \(A\) contains arbitrarily long arithmetic progressions; equivalently, **\(f(k)<\infty\) for every \(k\ge 3\)**. citeturn6view0turn1search3

#### The case \(k=3\): \(f(3)<\infty\) is known
Bloom–Sisask proved a Roth-type bound strong enough to break the logarithmic barrier: if \(A\subset\{1,\dots,N\}\) has no nontrivial 3-term AP, then
\[
|A|\ \ll\ \frac{N}{(\log N)^{1+c}}
\]
for some absolute \(c>0\). citeturn0search6

From this one gets \(f(3)<\infty\) by a standard counting-function/partial-summation argument. Concretely: for an infinite 3-AP-free \(A\), let \(A(x)=|A\cap[1,x]|\). Applying the finite-\(N\) extremal bound to \(A\cap[1,\lfloor x\rfloor]\) yields (for all sufficiently large \(x\))
\[
A(x)\ \le\ C\,\frac{x}{(\log x)^{1+c}}.
\]
Then partial summation gives, for \(N\ge 2\),
\[
\sum_{\substack{n\in A\\ n\le N}}\frac1n
= \frac{A(N)}{N}+\int_{1}^{N}\frac{A(x)}{x^2}\,dx
\ \ll\ 1+\int_{2}^{\infty}\frac{dx}{x(\log x)^{1+c}} \ <\ \infty,
\]
so \(\sum_{n\in A}\frac1n\) converges uniformly over 3-AP-free sets, hence \(f(3)<\infty\). citeturn0search6

#### The cases \(k\ge 4\): finiteness of \(f(k)\) is open
For \(k\ge 4\), it is currently unknown whether \(f(k)\) is finite. citeturn5view0turn6view0

It is worth stressing why existing quantitative forms of Szemerédi’s theorem do not settle this. For \(k=4\), Green–Tao proved
\[
r_4(N):=\max\{|A|\!:\!A\subset\{1,\dots,N\}\text{ is 4-AP-free}\}\ \ll\ N(\log N)^{-c}
\]
for some absolute \(c>0\). citeturn1search2  
But a bound of the form \(A(x)\ll x(\log x)^{-c}\) with \(c\le 1\) is still too weak to force convergence of \(\sum_{n\in A}\frac1n\), because the corresponding integral \(\int^\infty \frac{dx}{x(\log x)^c}\) diverges unless the exponent exceeds \(1\). Thus even the best-known \(k=4\) density bounds remain far from what would be needed to prove \(f(4)<\infty\). citeturn1search2

---

### Numerical records and Walker’s Kempner-set reduction (context)
As of Walker’s arXiv v2 (4 Sep 2025) and the current Erdős Problems entry (accessed 28 Jan 2026), the best published lower bounds for small \(k\) include:
- \(f(3)\ge 3.00849\), due to Wróblewski. citeturn1search24turn4search0  
- \(f(4)\ge 4.43975\), due to Walker. citeturn0search1turn2search0  

Walker also shows a structural reduction for *constructing near-extremisers*: if a \(k\)-AP-free set \(A\) has **convergent** \(\sum_{n\in A}\frac1n\), then for every \(\varepsilon>0\) one can find a \(k\)-AP-free **Kempner (digit-restricted)** set \(B\) with harmonic sum at least \(\sum_{n\in A}\frac1n-\varepsilon\). In particular, **if \(f(k)<\infty\)**, then \(f(k)\) can be approximated arbitrarily well by \(k\)-AP-free Kempner sets. citeturn2search0

---

### Bottom line for (i)
What is rigorously known at present can be summarized as:
- **Unconditional lower bounds:**  
  \[
  f(k)\ \ge\ \frac12\,H_{W(k)-1}\ \ge\ \frac12\log W(k)\quad\text{for all }k\ge 3,
  \]
  and
  \[
  f(k)\ \ge\ \frac{\log 2}{2}\,k\quad\text{(Berlekamp)},\qquad
  f(k)\ \ge\ (1-o(1))k\log k\quad\text{(Gerver)}.
  \]
  citeturn5view0turn1search0turn1search8
- **Upper bounds / finiteness:**  
  \(f(3)<\infty\) is known (Bloom–Sisask + partial summation), while for **every** \(k\ge 4\) it remains open whether \(f(k)<\infty\) (equivalently: the Erdős–Turán conjecture for \(k\)-term APs). citeturn0search6turn6view0

So for \(k\ge 4\) one only has meaningful one-sided estimates from below at present; any genuine two-sided asymptotic is blocked by a major open problem.

---

## (ii) Is \(\displaystyle \lim_{k\to\infty}\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}=\infty\)?

The unconditional van der Waerden averaging argument already gives
\[
\frac{f(k)}{\log W(k)}\ \ge\ \frac12\qquad (k\ge 3).
\]
citeturn5view0turn6view0

Beyond this, the situation is genuinely open: the Erdős Problems entry notes that **even improving** the constant \(\tfrac12\) to any uniform constant \(>\tfrac12\) is currently open. citeturn5view0  
Consequently, proving that the ratio actually tends to \(+\infty\) as \(k\to\infty\) is well beyond what is presently established.

(As a logical aside: if some \(f(k_0)=\infty\), then by monotonicity \(f(k)=\infty\) for all \(k\ge k_0\), and the ratio is trivially \(+\infty\) for all large \(k\). The interesting—and conjecturally relevant—case is when all \(f(k)\) are finite, i.e. the Erdős–Turán conjecture holds. citeturn6view0turn1search3)

**Conclusion:** the limit in (ii) is **open**; the best general lower bound remains the trivial \(\tfrac12\) coming from van der Waerden averaging. citeturn5view0

- Walker (arXiv:2203.06045, Sept 2025 revision) for \(f(4)\)-record and Kempner-set reduction,
- Green–Tao (2017) for quantitative Szemerédi bounds illustrating why finiteness remains open for \(k \ge 4\).

With rigorous statements, precise partial summation arguments, and careful separation of known results from open problems, this is a comprehensive, clear, and accurate final summary suitable for general readers and specialists alike.
